reviews.review_text: It's... not terrible.  As city builders go, it has issues, and if you own previous iterations of the game, then probably not worth it, but it isn't terrible at all.  In some ways it's deeper than Cities Skylines, in other ways it isn't, I miss districts, for example, but I actually prefer some of the mechanics and the 'feel' of XXL. There's plenty of content to unlock and the graphics work well, though not sure with the big-head design choice for the population.  I wouldn't rate it as the greatest game, or even the greatest City Builder I've ever played, but if you are a Builder fan, then, well, it's not terrible.

This being my first game for this franchise and not having played anything from Cities XL Platinum and before, I am quite impressed with this game. This has so far been worth my money and addictive and it's just fun cracking my brain and trying to solve whatever problem that comes up :) A whole new experience from Sim City 5! Rated 7/10

So, I wanted to give it some serious play time before attempting to critique this game. It recieved alot of harsh comments but all of them seem to be from people who were expecting some massive change from thier XL content. I have never owned Cities XL so I can say this XXL version is well worth the purchase. I love the global overview off the starts that allows me to basically build several citites on a continent and attempt to balance economies by trading between them. Its adictive...I find myself spending an hour or more on each city of mine daily to increase population and balance trade. No bugs or lag issues to speak of. I have a solid 30fps at all times even when conducting long roadway placements. One week in and I've got 4 cities up to 300,000 and each has a market niche to generate revenue. Once you find what your city excels at you can either trade to the game 'OMNICORP' for cash flow or use it to balance your other cities shortcomings. Stratigic thinking, decent graphics, larg scale cities & global economies make this a big winner in my book.

This was the first game in the series I bought, so I don't share the animosity others do about XXL being overpriced, but I still don't understand why people think the actual game is bad. It's actually very good imo. It's the most realistic city builder available, and the city builder which gives you the most flexibility in building. It can feel a bit lifeless in comparison to other modern city builders (notably CSL), and isn't that challenging, but it is my go to game for making beautiful, realistic cities.   As far as technical issues, the game runs fine for me. Had it bug out on me once when I tried to place a blueprint structure. In my latest city, I've filled about half the map and am getting 25-30 fps on medium graphics with a marginal GPU (although I do have a high-end CPU). Bridges and interchanges are a royal pain in the ♥♥♥, but other than that I find the user interface intuitive and easy to work with.

The game is MUCH better than any version before. Performance is way better, and by that I mean that it doesn't laaaaag after a city gets larger or after playing for a few hours. I know this because I did beta testing and I have hundreds and hundreds of hours playing Cities XL 2012 version. That laaag the previous versions had made a lot of people give up after reaching a certain population / city size. All that is now gone.  If you played any previous version and liked it then you will love this one.   If you are a new player and want a great city builder/planner that looks great and has large maps (11x11km) then look no further.  The game by it self is fun for some time. Like any other city builder you will get bored after making a few cities. That is the case in any Sim City game as well.  BUT! Thankfully the game has a great modding community which took this game to a whole new level. So you will never get bored because existing mods and new ones coming out on a regular basis will keep you hooked for a long time. There is a great comunnity forum that you just must check out:  www.xlnation.city   Don't listen to the trolls saying the game is not better, it's the same as before etc. etc. Like I said I have hundreds of hours in previous versions and this one is extremely improved. Yes it is the same in many ways which is a good thing considering that old mods will be compatible.   - It now spreads the workload of the game across all cores of the processor which makes it run smoother when the city gets larger. Is it true multicore or not doesn't really matter as long as the performance is better, and it is. - It now has DirectX 11 support - They added the workshop option - Now you can use fbx format to make mods - They added eco green upgrades for Heavy industry and Manufacturing buildings. Upgraded buildings produce much less polution. - It has some new transportation options (new park & ride bus system, new cargo airport) - New leisure buildings (including a large leisure airport, speed boat marina and a yacht marina) - New skyboxes to choose from (with clouds) - New parks - New polution reducing/enviroment improving buildings - New camera (just hit 'C' on the keyboard and use page up, page down / arrow keys / Ctrl button to move around)  All in all this is a great game if you want to have FUN making/designing your dream city be it modern american style city or an older looking european city or even an asian style city. Or maybe all of those on a single map. The possibilites, specially if you use mods, are endless.

Over the past week, city building fans have waited patitently for what they were hoping to be the definitive city builder since SimCity 4. Unfortunately the opinions of players has been mixed at best. So is Cities XXL better than Cities XL or worse in every way? We have heard people say this is just a re-branding of an old game, so we decided to find out for ourselves.  Cities XL first launched in 2009 and was a spiritual successor to City Life. The game offered expansive landscapes in which to build your dream city along with online capabilities (long before SimCity). However this did not live up to expectations, the online was a flop, the game suffered from poor optimization such as only using one core on multi-core systems and various memory leaks. Despite this, fans of the series have remained loyal. Despite its faults, Cities XL has offered a very fluid and flexible city building game.  When Cities XXL was announced, it was detailed to have an all new engine, more low-level micro-management and various improvements including to performance. These alone should make it a worthy upgrade or entry point for a budding city builder.  Well the first thing we questioned is the games engine. It is possible this is a new engine under the hood, but on the surface it looks very much the same engine as before. Graphically the game looks the same, albeit with a new black UI. The controls work much the same way and the menus are largely the same. So on the surface at least, the engine seems to have been tweaked rather than fully re-worked from the ground up.  Performance wise, this game is far better. Our city of 425k inhabitants is still as smooth as when we started. In Cities XL Platinum, a similar sized city we had suffered from terrible frame rates and choppiness at this point. The UI is also more responsive than before. We did encounter some minor graphical glitches, mostly that at night, streetlights would illuminate a grid beneath them. But nothing game breaking.  There are some new buildings to place in your city, like a pollution sensor and an eco-car dealer. There are not enough with too little function to add much weight behind a new game release, but welcome additions.  Talking of pollution, this has been greatly tweaked and works more the way you would expect. It makes more sense than ever before to ensure your industry is far from residential areas, where as before it was more of a case of “Does City have Heavy Pollution? Yes, City becomes polluted everywhere quickly”.  What we found most disappointing is there is not much of the low-level micro-management that was promised. What sets the Cities XL/XXL series apart from the SimCity series is the latter focuses much more on micro management and is more organic. In SimCity you say where you want residential, commercial and industrial areas, then depending on the desirability of the area would dictate what would be built there. This would not be static, you could have a luxury hi-rise apartment, but if crime in the area goes up this may become abandoned becoming an eyesore on your landscape. Cities XL/XXL cities generally remain the same, you will not find one neighborhood going from being desirable for Elites to suddenly becoming deserted.  Despite this short coming, one major addition that will help over time to make the Cities XXL the city building game we have been waiting for is the inclusion of the Steam Workshop. I really look forward to seeing the modding community making new buildings, new functions, improvements, fixes and potentially new functionality.  If you are a fan of the series, the current 50% discount off the price is very reasonable. Even not as a full game but £15 as a kind of expansion is not bad value. If you’ve never owned a game in this series and you want large sprawling cities rather than the small towns in SimCity then this is a game well worth picking up.

I normally dont review games but I wanted to throw in my 2 cents on this one. I love City builders and this game in all its versions has sersiously frustrated me. It's a good game but just as you get going in the previous versions it would lag to an unplayable state.  That being said, I want to note a few things for people that are considering buying this for first time as well as upgrading.  1) So far im well past population where issues start occuring in the old version and I have flawless performance. So the folks on here and youtube that are stating there is no performance increase I'm calling BS.  2) It's a GREAT City builder that got a bad rep because of past versions performance issues (this HAS been fixed)  Now on to a few points concerning the company. Do I think they are shady and does it anger me that I had to pay 20 bucks for a patch? Yes Is this the same game reskinned? Yes Is it a bad game? NO  The people raging on Steam are simply ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that this isn't a new game. I watched the trailers and any people that has played the previous games would know by looking at the trailers that it was the same game. What do you expect? They have released 3 'new versions' that were literally the same game. I didnt expect any less. I just wanted the performance fixed so I could enjoy the damn game for what it was and unfortunately I was forced to pay $20 to do so.  Focus you should be ASHAMED for treating your players like that.  They said a long time ago that the game needed to be rebuilt to get multicore support and maybe thats how the justified the 'new game' this time. But its the same game WITH MULTICORE. People are saying there is no multicore support when indeed there is you can see it in your CPU monitor.   Is it even across all cores? No, but it works and it runs great.  So take the complaining with a grain of salt. A lot of people expected something different when the trailers clearly showed the same damn game and anyone that spent any time in XL knows it.  Thanks and I hope this helps you buy or not buy the game. As for me, I am enjoying it and going to recommend it based on the fact I got it @ 50% off (still a ♥♥♥♥ off) and I am actually able to play it again. Also going to up vote to help counter the RAGE reviews.  I want to DOWN vote it based on Focus being a slimy money grubbing company that treats their gamers like crap.

It's only just come out (5th Feb 2015) but already I've played it enough to know it's an almost exact clone of the predeecing version (XL Platinum), the only difference being that the GUI has had a 'Windows 8.1' makeover (it's turned funeral grey and is bordeless). Otherwise, it's the same game it ever was, complete with stutters and jutters and rather poorly realised calculation tables that means as the city gets larger, the whole thing slows down. This was always a talking point of earlier versions, but looks like the programmers have simply ignored all suggestions (yet again...!). I've yet to get a really big city going, but a medium sized one is already showing signs of buckling under the claculations strain.  Despite this, it's still a better game (in my view) than it's big-company rival Sim City, with its kiddy graphics and sandbox square townships. It will appeal to those who just want to get on with building a city, along more accurate simulation models. Just be prepared to fill your swear box when things start grinding to a standstill. Oh, and they've changed the muzak yet again. Nice touch that.

This feels like the same game as Cities XL, which I already own. The interface, the building tools, the game mechanics all seems the same to me.   What's different?  * Allegedly performance does not fall apart so badly in the end game as with Cities XL * Some new content * Steam Achievements * Steam Workshop  Pretty sure engine, achievements, and workshop could have been a game update for cities XL, and the new pieces of content could have been DLC for cities XL.   So why did I buy the same game released under a new name? Somehow I thought it would be a different game. Perhaps because it is sold as a different game. But it seems to just be a port of mostly the same game to a new engine.  Why would you buy this?  * You don't already own Cities XL and the game is on sale * You desperately want the steam achievements and the game is on sale * You desperately want the steam workshop support and the game is on sale * You desperately want the new content and the game is on sale  Even at the 50% pre-order price offered to those who already owned Cities XL, this seems like a well played con job.   Other developers have demonstrated how to update existing games with additions like steam achievements, 64bit builds, engine updates, additional content, etc.. It's a shame that Focus decided to ignore the good examples set by others, instead pulling an insulting scam of a strategy out of their rear ends.

TLDR: Close to being such a good game and yet so far away. Overall it comes across as having all the ingredients to be the the greatest city building game ever, and If they fixed some of the flaws it would be great, as it is, I just can't recommend it.  I know of the big furore over this game essentially being a poor update on a previously released title 'Cities XL', but I never bought those games and cannot judge this game against it; this review will just be of the game on its own and in isolation. If anything my comparison point would be 'SimCity 4', because like most people we've all just been crying out for a sequel to that game that has never happened (at least not how we wanted it, looking at you SimCity Societies).  The Good: - You can build a city as pretty as the pictures above, it's all very zen. - The music is quite nice and generally the onscreen notifications aren't overwhelming or irritating. - Gameplay is fairly intuitive with nicely varied levels of difficulty, especially if you're used to the city building game format. - The trading system is balanced meaning specialisation of a city can be done easily, you want to build a tourist paradise or an farming utopia? Knock yourself out, it's a lot of flexibility with how you play.  The Bad: - Poor terrain modification tools, the maps look how they look and you'd better like it. - The UI is a little bit clunky, occasionally you'll miss-click things. - Zoom out a little bit and all the vehicles turn to weird grey/black boxes on the road. It upsets your zen greatly. - I can build individual buildings to a style or I can basically pot-luck it with the city zoning, I can't just set a style of building? You crazy. - Roads vs Terrain, being unable to properly terraform the landscape makes this maddening however. - The tutorial thinks it's funny.  The Ugly: - This game will crash on you, a lot, regularly. - Lag. Laaaaaaaaggggggg.  Verdict: If they got rid of the ugly, you could live with the bad, with both however you end up struggling to play the game, this then magnifies any flaws with the game. Like old Lara Crofts terrible camera angles, or resident evils weird control schemes, you fight with them for a while and then you put the game down and you just never pick it up again.
